question: Question_07_(b)
sols:
We will denote $f(x,y) = \frac{dx}{dt}(x,y) = x(2 - x  - y)$ and
$g(x,y) = \frac{dy}{dt}(x,y) = y(1-x)$. Then the Jacobian matrix at at
point $(x,y)$ is

\[J(x,y) = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
f_x(x,y) & f_y(x,y) \\ g_x(x,y) & g_y(x,y)
\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 - 2x - y & -x \\ -y & 1-x
\end{array}\right).\]
hints:
The Jacobian matrix is the matrix of all the first-order partial
derivatives.

Let \emph{f(x,y)} and \emph{g(x,y)} be the right hand side of x' and y',
respectively. Then the Jacobian matrix is

:J = \textbackslash{}left(\textbackslash{}begin\{array\}\{cc\} f\_x \&
f\_y \textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} g\_x \& g\_y
\textbackslash{}end\{array\}\textbackslash{}right)
